title: Gareth Southgate considers return to three at the back after England's damning defeat to Czech Republic
text:
Gareth Southgate is considering returning to the defensive back line of three centre-halves and wing-backs that England adopted for last summer’s World Cup finals, and then tried to leave behind as they embarked on the next phase of their development.

The England manager was speaking after Friday’s surprise 2-1 loss to the Czech Republic, making it five goals conceded in the past two Euro 2020 qualifiers. While Southgate is not minded to go to three at the back ahead of Monday’s qualifier against Bulgaria in Sofia, he concedes something must change ahead of next year’s finals.

England gave up a chance to qualify early for the tournament with defeat in Prague so must win their final three games to be sure of topping Group A. Even if they do, they are no longer guaranteed to be one of the six top seeds and could even face the prospect of being placed in the same group as world champions France, or Belgium.

Michael Keane’s partnership with Harry Maguire looks shaky and the likelihood is that Southgate will turn to Joe Gomez. He now faces some serious selection decisions especially with players who, in his view, are struggling at their clubs.

Southgate said: “I think we are in a difficult situation in terms of the players that have played international football with us in that area of the pitch [defence] and who are playing regularly with their clubs. So, that’s part of the reason we didn’t do that [switch to a three-man back line against the Czechs]. It’s certainly something we’ve considered and I don’t think we can dismiss. I’m not sure, ahead of Monday, if that’s the right thing to do but we’re very aware and assessing those things.”
